Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common.path

Class PathWalker

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.common.path.PathWalker
  • public final class PathWalker
extends Object
    Reads or writes one or more values within a given Object using Path objects to specify which fields to read/write. No exceptions are thrown if a path could not be walked all the way to the last path segment due to:

    • one of the intermediate path segments referenced a null value
    • the path is invalid given the type of the object to read/write
    • an array index was expected but not found in the path
    • the array index was out of bounds
    • the path continued after having reached a terminal value within the object (a primitive)

    In all of these cases the path's value is set to null or DEAD_END (depending on your choice), but no exception is thrown. Only if a segment did correspond to a field, but accessing the field caused an IllegalAccessException, a PathWalkerException wrapping the IllegalAccessException is thrown.

    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

    • Field Detail

      • DEAD_END

        public static final Object DEAD_END
        A special value indicating that a path could not be walked all the way to the end for the object currently being read. Note that this can either mean that you really specified an invalid path given the type of object to walk, or that the object did not have the nested objects corresponding to the path.

      • PathWalker

        public PathWalker​(List<Path> paths,
                  boolean useDeadEndValue)
        Creates a MapReader for the specified paths. If useDeadEndValue equals true, then the value for a path that could not be walked will be DEAD_END, else null. If it is important to distinguish between "real" null values and dead ends, pass true.
        Parameters:
        paths -
        useDeadEndValue -

      • PathWalker

        public PathWalker​(List<Path> paths,
                  boolean useDeadEndValue,
                  BiFunction<Map,​String,​Object> mapKeyDeserializer)
        Creates a MapReader for the specified paths. If useDeadEndValue equals true, then the value for a path that could not be walked will be DEAD_END, else null. If it is important to distinguish between "real" null values and dead ends, pass true. If you need to read from or write to maps with non-string keys, you must provide a function that converts path segments to map keys.
        Parameters:
        paths - The paths to walk
        useDeadEndValue - Whether to use DEAD_END or null for paths that could not be walked all the way to the end
        mapKeyDeserializer - A function that converts strings to map keys (may be null if no deserialization is required). The map being read is passed as the 1st argument to the function; the path segment to be deserialized as the 2nd argument.

    • Method Detail

      • readValues

        public Object[] readValues​(Object host)
                    throws PathWalkerException
        Returns the values of all paths within the provided object in the same order as the paths specified through the constructor.
        Parameters:
        host - The object to read the path values from
        Returns:
        Throws:
        PathWalkerException

      • readValues

        public void readValues​(Object host,
                       Object[] output)
                throws PathWalkerException
        Reads the values of all paths within the provided object and places them in the provided output array. The values will be in the same order as the paths specified through the constructors. The output array need not have the same length as the path array.
        Parameters:
        host -
        output -
        Throws:
        PathWalkerException

        Parameters:

        Throws:

      • read

        public <T> T read​(Object obj)
        Returns the value of the first path. Useful if the PathWalker was created with just one path.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the object that the path points to
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to read the path values from
        Returns:
        Throws:
        PathWalkerException

      • writeValues

        public void writeValues​(Object host,
                        Object... values)
        Sets the values of all paths within the provided object to the specified values. The number of values must be greater than or equal to the length as the number of Path objects specified through the constructor.
        Parameters:
        host -
        values -

      • write

        public void write​(Object host,
                  Object value)
        Sets the value of the first path within the provided object to the specified value. Useful if the PathWalker was created for just one path. This method will not throw an exception if path's parent does not exist within the provided object, or if the value of the path's parent is null. It will also not throw an exception when trying to set a value at an index that is out of bounds for the provided host object. It may throw a ClassCastException, however.
        Parameters:
        host -
        value -
